abstract.text: A data structure that models a set of specific questions, their possible answers, and the actions that follow from a series of answers.

inlineContent.text: You can define a decision tree manually, by specifying questions, answers, and actions, or you can allow the
class to automatically learn a predictive model based on example data. A decision tree has several elements:
represent individual questions to be answered or choices to be made.
are the possible answers to the questions or choices posed by each attribute.
are the final outcomes of the tree’s decision-making process. Each branch from an attribute leads either to another attribute or to an action.

class, attributes and actions can be any object type relevant to your app or game. You can define branches for specific answer values, using predicates, or with weights that influence a random decision. For example, a strategy combat game might use a decision tree to choose what a character should do on its turn, based on several criteria about the match in progress. In this case:
For attributes, you might use (non-user-visible) strings that represent those criteria, such as
(what type of enemy is the character’s opponent?),
(how much health does the opponent have remaining?), and
(is the character’s special move available for use?).
For branches, you’d use an appropriate style for each attribute. The
attribute might have a branch for each possible enemy type, but the
attribute could use predicates to determine whether the enemy’s health is above or below a certain threshold value.
For actions, you might define your own enumerated type representing the kinds of attacks the character can choose (such as
). Alternately, you might use instances of your own custom classes representing items or spells available to the character.
illustrates a possible tree structure based on the above example attributes, branches, and actions.
class offers two ways to create decision trees.

, you define each attribute to be tested (or question to be asked), the possible branches (or answers) from each attribute, and the actions (or final outcomes) resulting from each complete series of attribute tests and branches. To manually create a tree, start by using the
initializer to define the first question to be asked. Then, use
object to define branches and the child nodes they lead to, with accompanying attribute or action values.

, you provide a set of attributes (or questions); a body of example items, each of which represents a set of attribute values (or answers to questions); and the final action to be taken for each example. The

class then automatically infers a decision tree structure that, when presented with a set of attribute values matching or similar to one of your examples, predicts the corresponding action. To create a learned decision tree, use the
initializer. The following table shows sample input for a learned decision tree (based on the same hypothetical game shown in
After creating either kind of decision tree, you can use the inherited
After you’ve created a tree, use the

method to evaluate it and choose an action. When you call that method, you provide a set of inputs (values for attributes, or answers to questions), and the tree follows the branches corresponding to each input value to produce an action.
When defining an attribute with a small set of possible values, define your own enum type to name the possible values. Then use the underlying numeric value of that enum when building trees with the
initializer, and when passing a set of attribute values to the
For example, the following code evaluates a tree similar to the examples in

abstract.text: A textual representation of the receiver.
Architect and organize your game logic. Incorporate common gameplay behaviors such as random number generation, artificial intelligence, pathfinding, and agent behavior.
A node for use in manually creating decision trees, representing a specific question and possible answers, or an action that follows from answering other questions.
Creates a child node that the decision tree should use when the current node’s attribute has the specified value.
A data structure that models a set of specific questions, their possible answers, and the actions that follow from a series of answers.
Searches the decision tree, following the branches corresponding to each of the specified answers, and returns the resulting action object.
Creates a decision tree starting with the specified initial attribute to test.
Creates an automatically learned decision tree using the specified attributes, example items, and actions.
The randomizer to be used when evaluating parts of the tree that branch randomly.
The decision node at the root of the decision tree, representing the first attribute to test.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
